section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy:Read-Aloud Comprehension; Print Concepts; Alphabet Knowledge

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Aa and Bb, engage children in a song about friends, and introduce vocabulary (thank-you note).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What good manners does Clifford have?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Alphabet Books An Attic, The Bath

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Introduce children to the letters Aa and Bb.
Encourage children to identify the sounds /a/ and /b/.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does your book have friends? Tell me about them.
Pretend you are at a restaurant. How can you use good manners?
How can you use manners to work on a puzzle with a friend?
What can you draw and write about your friend?
What can you make to give to a friend to say “thank you”? What materials will you choose?
How can you use the modeling clay to make the letters Aa and Bb you saw on the Alphabet Cards?
How can you use your manners to share the blocks with a friend? What can you say?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1987 by Norman Bridwell.Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Demonstrate Empathy Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (please, excuse me).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Clifford’s Manners.
Read closely to notice and talk about when Clifford shows empathy.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Demonstrate empathy for others
engage in conflict resolution.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Encourage children to create happy flowers.
Talk about when and why they might give someone a happy flower.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you and a friend want to read the same book, can you show me a good way to solve the problem?
Pretend you want to play a game, but your friend doesn’t want to. How can you fix the problem?
Can you sort the pattern blocks with a friend?
Can you use stamps and stickers to write your friend’s name on a friendship card?
Can you make a friendship necklace? Why did you choose to use those materials?
Can you find the first letter of your name and the first letter of a friend’s name?
What can you and a friend build together with the blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1987 by Norman Bridwell.Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTMillustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Neirfy/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (manners).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Clifford’s Manners and asking, When does Clifford use good manners?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Vote as part of a group to make decisions.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Walk children through the voting process.
Guide children’s understanding of the value of the voting process.
Count votes with children to determine the most-chosen activity.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find examples of good and bad manners in a book?
Pretend you and a friend are going to the park. What will you do there?
How many different ways can you sort the connecting cubes? Show me and count the ways.
What would you say in an email to a friend you miss? Can you draw and write about it?
How can you make a class voting box for when we take votes? What will you use?
How can you write letters in the shaving cream? Can you make Aa and Bb? Can you make the first letter of your name?
How can you build a doghouse for Clifford?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1987 by Norman Bridwell.Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Lucie Lang), pencils (urfin).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Thank You, Friend!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about being a good friend, use friendly introductions, and introduce vocabulary (take turns).
Begin Story Time by connecting Clifford’s Manners and Thank You, Friend!
Read interactively and connect to the Concept Question, How can we be a good friend to others?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Distinguish letters, words, and pictures.
Select books and other texts for pre-reading.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Demonstrate empathy for others
engage in conflict resolution.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Chart Paper, Colored Paper, Art Supplies

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to make thank-you notes.
Talk about different ways to be a good friend.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find two books about being a friend? Which one do you like better? Why?
What could you say to a friend when you first see each other?
Can you use connecting cubes to make three different lengths? Which is shortest? longest?
Why would you send someone a thank-you note? What would you write on it?
Do you think you can make a mask that you can use when you play dress-up with a friend?
Can you write the first letter of your name in the sand tray?
Can you put the cars in order from smallest to largest?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford’s Manners by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1987 by Norman Bridwell.Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Print Concepts; Writing

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children sing and dance as they share ways classmates are good friends and to review vocabulary.
Begin story time by revisiting the book and asking, How do you show you have good manners?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Distinguish letters, words, and pictures.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Demonstrate empathy for others.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Why do you want to be a good friend to others?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book about friends. Can you find words that begin with Aa or Bb?
Choose two dolls and pretend they are friends at a park. What do they say to each other?
Can you use the counters to figure out how many friends are in our class?
Can you write to tell a friend why you like playing together?
Can you create a drawing of you and a friend playing?
Look at the Alphabet Cards for Aa and Bb. Can you write the letters on paper?
Can you create a playground out of blocks? Can you pretend the plastic people are playing there? How do they use manners?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Identify good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Engage in voting as a method for group decision-making.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in pre-reading behaviors.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Retell or re-enact a story after it is read aloud.
Distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
